III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS & CONCLUSIONS
A. Physical Description of Facility
This agency, Lifeline Children’s Services INC. will be located at 17105 W. 12 Mile
Rd., Southfield, MI. 48076. Currently, this space is occupied by Christian Family
Services, Protestant Youth Organization (CFS PYO). Once Lifeline’s license is
issued, Christian Family Services license will close, and the title of the building will
be switched over to Lifeline Children’s Services INC. The building was built in
1958 and the agency space is approximately 1920 square feet.
2

The agency contains; 1 waiting area/lobby, 10 offices, 1 conference room, a
basement with a separate locked storage area, two bathrooms (one upstairs one
in basement). Office areas are comfortable and sizable for clients and employees.
Some offices are set up and furnished for seating for multiple clients and
associates. Offices are comfortable and functional. Lifeline files will be stored in
the back-office area on first floor. Lifeline plans to digitize all files as well. There
are two bathrooms. The main bathroom on the main level is used for clients and
employees. The building has a right wing and left wing divided by the lobby/wait
area in the middle. The right side contains hallway connecting 5 offices and a
bathroom. The left wing includes a step down and entrance with lock to basement,
conference room, and 5 additional offices. There is a cross shredder and file
cabinets with a lock due to applicant fingerprints. This file cabinet is secured at all
times.
There is a handicap spot in the parking lot and a handicap accessible ramp
exterior entrance in the back of the building leading into the conference room and
connected to the parking lot. Parking lot is on the side and back of the building
and partitioned with a wall dividing business area from neighborhood. There are
approximately 8 parking spots in the back of the building. The building contains
exterior double locks on the two exterior doors for its security system. Lifeline
plans to install video doorbell and a ring security system.
B. Program Description
The following information was provided by the agency and reviewed: Policies and
procedures, all annual budgets, and financial accounts for the fiscal year. Also
reviewed were the agency statement of need, articles of incorporation document
and non-profit status.
Lifeline will be placing children for adoption and evaluating applicants for
adoption. Lifeline program statement says, the agency exists to equip the Body of
Christ to manifest the gospel to vulnerable children, such as children who have
experienced trauma or children who are orphans. Lifeline defines orphan as the
child must have no parents, or a sole or surviving parent who is unable to care for
the child and has, in writing, irrevocably released the child for emigration and
adoption. Orphan care is serving orphans through adoption, education,
discipleship, life skills, etc. Additionally, Lifeline defines vulnerable children by any
child the agency serves outside of the orphan definition who have experienced,
hurt, trauma, homelessness, etc. that are not available for adoption. Lifeline’s
purpose is to provide a hope and a future through the gospel for vulnerable
children around the world by discipling, engaging, and equipping the body of
Christ. Lifeline of Michigan will achieve this through domestic and international
adoption programs, as well as equipping the church to provide support and
3

training to families in need. Lifeline believes vulnerable children and their
communities are transformed by the gospel and are making disciples. The core
values of Lifeline are gospel-driven, discipleship-focused, excellence-directed,
biblically integrous, local church-centered, birth parent reconciliation and
redemption, global compassion, and holistic care.
Lifeline seeks to help families in Michigan who wish to grow their family through
adoption. This will be completed through home studies, training and education,
pre-placement and post placement support, and post adoption services including
counseling. Most adoptions are from private clients which is a part of the agency
referral source. Lifeline will determine adoption eligibility through an orientation
and home study process to ensure that Michigan regulations and Lifeline
requirements are met before completion. Lifeline is a faith-based nonprofit
ministry which partners with families who align with the agency faith and the
tenets of their beliefs. The agency process includes a pre-application including the
requirement of agreement with the statement of faith, which is based on orthodox
Christian doctrine; these include both marriage and faith. If both spouses cannot
agree with the agency statement of faith or have different views or beliefs than the
agency, the agency respects that and will gladly connect the family with an
agency that more closely aligns with their beliefs and interests. The agency will
work with single women in select countries and will partner with their international
adoption programs for additional services.
C. Rule/Statutory Violations
None.
4

Based on substantial compliance with the rules, it is recommended that a six-month
original license be issued.
